Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2007 01:16PM msfriz6 wrote: Hello ladies, I guess this is where I need to be.  So, here's a little background:   9/10/07 Dx: IDC lf br, Grade II 10/10/07 Bi-lateral (my choice) 10/16/07 Path report: Stage III, 4cm, 5/12 nodes+, ER+, PR+, HER2- 10/25/07 Power Port placement (local with conscious sedation)              Mugga test              PET scan  10/30/07 1st chemo (TAC, 6tx, every 3 weeks) Neulasta Have survived the first 10 days.  I just turned 43, SAHM with 6 kids (14-7), live in rural KS, married 18 yrs to a 4th generation farmer/rancher.  Travel 3.5 hrs/each way for treatment.  Makes for some very long days! What a journey this has been thus far!  I am so glad to see, I am not alone in tackling this BUMP in life. HUGS to all~
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2007 12:28PM msfriz6 wrote: I feel extremely blessed to have found this board where I can relate to so many.  What a comforting feeling.  Thank you, ladies! I also feel blessed God chose this path for me.  So much growth can be obtained through suffering.  I and those connected to me, have the potential to learn numerous lessons.  I hope and pray we are opened to hear, see and understand that which we are to learn. Miss_Lolli ~ Thanks for the comment.  I can see what a supportive group this is.  It's awesome!  Yep, I kind of felt like a fish out of water, with no one to relate to that is going through similiar situations.  Until now, that is.  What kind of puppy to you have?  We have a Border Collie as she helps us work cattle.  It's amazing how much natural instinct they have.  Hope you can get out to the park again, soon! Kara ~ Thanks for the link.  I highly doubt I would've found it on my own.  I haven't really looked around much, yet.  The link is full of useful information!  Enjoy Ratatouille, what a fun movie. My kids and I loved it!  Congrads on #3!!  Stay strong. TexanKaren ~ Thanks for the welcome!  45 min. is still a lot longer than most people, I imagine.  I love living in a rural community (pop. 200) as it's a great place to raise kids, but it does have it's downfalls as everything is so far away.  OMG, 30 chairs???  My center has 10.  I can't even imagine!  I will keep you in my prayers for safe traveling! carpediempenny ~ Ahhh, a fellow TAC-er!!  I go for my 2nd tx on the 20th.  Wow, still working through all this?  You have GUTS!  Do you think your 2nd round was like the first??  I can't help but wonder how it will go... better... worse??  Any words of advice?? mrs7148 ~  I think our schedules are within a couple days of each other.  My #2 is on Nov., 20 and I should finish on Feb., 12!!  Are you on TAC, as well?  Amazing you metioned the Ozarks.  We took our family vacation there this past summer, renting a 65' houseboat.  We had a blast!  Nice area, but I understand your reservations about getting good medical care.  Congradulations to your dh's remission!!  I'd say, you guys have had more than your share of 'speed bumps'!  My hats off to you!  You mentioned your wbc being 13.8 - mine went from 1.9 (6 days post 1st tx) to 27.5 (10 days post).  I knew the Neulasta was supposed to boost the wbc production, but I had no idea it would blast it off the chart!  Hope your platelets rise soon! Day 14 (post #1) - I feel well, but tired.  I really shouldn't complain because I think I am getting off easy as far as SE.  But, it is hard to lie low when I am used to being on the go.  Still very much enjoy playing the violin (began 1 yr ago) and have pulled out a bunch of Christmas music in preparation for playing in the choir at Church.  I play each weekend, but Christmas is such a special time!  Hopefully, this year my kids will join me.  One child plays the alto sax - another the trombone & guitar - another the clarinet, flute, & violin - another the banjo - another the violin - and the last a chello that is tuned like a bass violin.  I LOVE hearing music in the house.  It warms my soul! Have a good week, ladies!!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2007 12:21PM msfriz6 wrote: Great thread!  Thanks marlee1 for getting it started.  My decision to forgo reconstruction after bi-lat, 10/10/07 (1 necessary other prophylactic) was easy.  I was very flat-chested before surgery (never wore a bra) and am not much different, now.  (A lumpectomy wasn't even an option - the 4cm tumor was my entire breast)  The only difference now, is that I don't have any nipples, either.  Before surgery, I thought I'd have that part reconstructed eventually, but now I'm not going to.  Just no need - for me personally. That being said, my husband of 18 years did attemp to talk me into getting the 'Dolly Parton' look.  I told him, surgery wouldn't end there bc I would need 'butt augmentation, otherwise I would be falling on my nose.  Yea, I am sure from his point of view, it'd be nice.  But in my mind, my breasts or lack-there-of, never defined me as me.  So, no thank you. Karen1956 ~ Your post caught my eye as I see you are from Denver.  That's where I go for tx (live 3.5 hours away, though).  Do you by any chance go to the Cancer Care Center at Porter Hosp?  I am heading back for #2 on the 20th.  Oh, and I saw a great PS that I'd highly recommend.  Could maybe get you in before Jan., if you are interested?? Peace and strength to all ~
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools
